bioghist.p: The Michigan Association for Media in Education (MAME) came into being on January 1, 1974, when two earlier organizations merged for the potential power and influence of greater numbers. The two predecessors, the Michigan Association of School Librarians (MASL) and the Michigan Audio-Visual Association (MAVA) built on such traditions as joint conferences, newsletters, and committees in establishing the new organization.

Mrs. Lois T. Place, Director of School Libraries of the Detroit Public Schools, was the guiding spirit behind MASL, organizing a small group of librarians who met in November of 1949. Additional planning meetings, with growing numbers of participants, were held in the spring of 1950, and the first meeting of the Steering Committee occurred on July 12 of that year. The constitution of the new organization, with a charter membership of sixty-five, was ratified at the November 3-4, 1950 Charter Meeting, held at Haven Hill Lodge in Milford, Michigan. In addition to providing school librarians with an opportunity to share problems and ideas, the new organization was aimed at promoting better understanding among school librarians, administrators, teachers and students.

According to its constitution, dated December 1, 1950, the Michigan Audio-Visual Association, with a charter membership of forty, was established to "advance education through the more efficient selection, utilization, evaluation, and administration of the audio-visual materials of instruction."

A Merger Exploration Committee sent a study questionnaire to MASL and MAVA members in early 1972, and reported favorable results at the Spring Combined Conference. A Constitutional Revision Committee was appointed shortly thereafter, and overwhelming approval of the results of their efforts was announced at the 1973 Combined Conference. On December 31, 1973, both MASL and MAVA ceased to exist. On January 1, 1974, MAME, a new educational media organization with a membership soon to surpass 1,000, was born.

scopecontent.p: The record group is divided into four series: Michigan Association of School Librarians (MASL); Michigan Audio-Visual Association (MASL); MASL-MAVA combined activities; and Michigan Association for Media in Education.

scopecontent.p: The bulk of the record group is comprised of the records of the Michigan Association of School Librarians. In the original order imposed by the organization, records are arranged by school year and thereafter by administrative function or document type. Sample file designations include Board of Directors, Board Meetings, Conferences, Publicity, Correspondence, Regions and Supervisors, SLAAM (Student Library Assistant Association of Michigan), Annual Reports, and History. Although there is slight variation from year to year, and clear evidence of the organization's growth in both size and complexity, file organization remains essentially the same. A file organization chart provided by MASL is included in the file "MASL: Miscellaneous 1973-1974" in Box 3. Material types in administrative function files include calendars of events, membership lists, meeting agendas and minutes, treasurer's reports, conference programs and planning information, and committee reports. A set of MASL newsletters is also included, as are three scrapbooks which further document the organization's history. Although the scrapbooks duplicate some materials in the files, they also provide a more personal look at the organization through informal photographs, souvenir items such as name tags and autographed programs, newsclippings, and annotations. Files and scrapbooks combine to form a comprehensive picture of MASL's history.

scopecontent.p: Michigan Audio-Visual Association records, identified as "History" in the file designations, are very similar to those of MASL, both in material types and organization. Again, original order has been retained.
The MASL-MAVA series concerns the 1973 Combined Conference and the Constitutional Committee.

did.unittitle: Michigan Association for Media in Education

scopecontent.p: The Michigan Association for Media in Education material, the bulk of which was received in 2009, includes two principal sub-series: History and Conferences. Each of these is comprised of binders arranged by year. The History volumes include constitution and articles of incorporation; membership materials; board of directors minutes and financial material; records of organization officers, divisions, standing committees, and affiliates; and newsletters and various subject files. Each of the binders contains a detailed index. The Conference volumes relate to the yearly meeting of the organization and include agendas, programs, evaluations and related material. Other MAME materials include scrapbooks, publication of the organization, and miscellaneous sound cassettes and photographic slides.
